items.entry: A humanoid skeleton clad in rusted armour holding a {@item silvered weapon|phb|silvered, nonmagical weapon} (your choice) with {@dice 1d4} magic items in a mouldy satchel (roll on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 11–15.
items.entry: A humanoid corpse clutching a weapon (your choice) and a pouch containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems.

items.name: 15–17.
items.entry: A smashed {@item chest|phb} containing a dozen battered books, {@dice 1d4} {@item trinket|phb|trinkets} (see chapter 5, "{@book Equipment|phb|6|Trinkets}" of the {@i Player's Handbook}) and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table B} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

items.name: 18–19.
items.entry: A monster hoard containing {@dice 2d6} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table C} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).
A slain adventurer atop a monster hoard containing {@dice 3d4} 50 gp gems and {@dice 1d4} magic items (roll on {@table Magic Item Table D} in chapter 7 on the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Travellers
entries: The characters encounter one or more travellers (use the {@creature commoner} stat block) with a tale to tell:

entries.name: Road/Trail
entries: Either of the following:

items: {@dice 3d6} peasants fleeing their homes after a pirate raid or sea spawn attack.
An angry mob of {@dice 6d6} peasants looking to reclaim their land or avenge loved ones.
A lone merchant or minstrel in a horse-drawn {@item wagon|phb} who is relocating to a safer settlement

footnotes.name: Wolves
entries: The party encounter a pack of {@dice 1d6 + 5} {@creature wolf|mm|wolves}.

entries.name: Night
entries: The {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} are hunting and attack the characters' camp. A character on watch with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher notices the pack surveying the camp. If unnoticed, the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} surprise the characters.

entries.name: Day
entries: The characters discover a den where the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} are sleeping. Unless the party disguise their scent, the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} attack their camp the following night.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, the pack is accompanied by {@dice 1d3} {@creature dire wolf|mm|dire wolves}.

footnotes.name: Coelenites
entries: The characters are attacked by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) who try and pull them down into the water and drown them. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} try to avoid leaving the ocean if possible but foray onto the shore or climb aboard boats to pursue their prey.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are 4th level or higher, replace one of the {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} with a {@creature coelenite mass mind|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} telepathically threaten the characters with drowning unless they provide a tribute of food. The {@creature coelenite|CallfromtheDeep|coelenites} can be appeased with food (four day's supply per coelenite in the group). Otherwise, they attack.

footnotes.name: Dolphins
entries: The characters spot a pod of {@dice 3d4} {@creature dolphin|vgm|dolphins} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). If the characters are above the surface of the water, they notice the beautiful creatures leaping between the waves. They are naturally inquisitive and might come within 10 feet of the boat to take a look.

A {@creature dolphin|vgm} that is successfully {@condition grappled}, caught in a {@item net|phb}, or otherwise prevented from escaping can be trained as a mount by a character with proficiency in {@skill Animal Handling} who spends a few hours a day working with the mammal. At the end of 1 week, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. On a success, the dolphin becomes a willing mount for any humanoid.

entries.name: Sea
entries: If this encounter occurs at sea, the characters encounter {@dice 3d6} friendly sea elf {@creature scout|mm|scouts}. These elves might be from Tir faoi Thoinn, Iumathiashae, or Waterdeep. They know the location of all the Island Kingdoms and underwater locations. Characters can hire a sea elf guide for 1 gp a day.

There is a {@chance 10} chance that one of the aquatic elves is a {@creature malenti|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}); a sahuagin born with a mutation that makes it resemble an aquatic elf. The malenti spies on the characters as best it can and reports back to its sahuagin allies when it can about their movements and plans. This information eventually makes its way to the Colony of Zellix'Phor and could be used to set up an ambush with one of the mind flayers when the characters made port.

footnotes.name: Floating Debris
entries: The characters notice something floating one hundred feet away. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals the nature of the debris. Roll a {@dice d6}:

items.name: 1–3.
entries: Barrels and crates.

items.name: 4–5.
entries: Shattered wooden planks.
Chests.

entries.name: Barrels and Crates
entries: Bobbing on the waves are {@dice 4d4} crates and {@item barrel|phb|barrels} filled with goods. These may contain alcohol, {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, rope or other basic items typically found aboard ships.

entries.name: Shattered Wooden Planks
entries: Planks of shattered wood float atop the ocean. Clearly, these are remnants of a ship which has been recently attacked and perhaps destroyed. There is a {@chance 50} chance that a pirate ship is nearby (see "Pirate Ship" in this section).

entries.name: Chests
entries: Mostly sunk beneath the water's surface are {@dice 1d4} {@item chest|phb|chests}. These must have been jettisoned from another vessel. The {@item chest|phb|chests} are locked and keyless and require a successful DC 14 Dexterity check with {@item thieves' tools|phb} or a successful DC 16 Strength check to open. Inside are valuable items worth 100 gp, such as money, gems, candlesticks, jewellery and the like. There is a {@chance 10} chance that the chest contains a more expensive item worth 250 gp, such as a gemstone or {@table 250 gp art objects|dmg|art object}. This could be replaced with a magic item (roll once on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}).

footnotes.name: Ghost Ship
entries: A merchant ship appears on the horizon but appears to be drifting very slowly. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check reveals that the deck is empty, and the ship appears to be adrift.

If the characters decide to board the ship, they discover that it is entirely empty. There is a {@chance 50} chance that they can salvage useful items from the vessel such as {@item rations (1 day)|phb|rations}, alcohol, rope and the like.

entries.name: Haunted
entries: There is a {@chance 50} chance that the ship is haunted by the dead crew. If so, there are {@dice 3d4} {@creature ghost|mm|ghosts} aboard the ship who lash out at characters that disrespect the ship by stealing, breaking into cabins etc. If characters can calm the ghosts by offering them eternal rest, they reveal that their ship was attacked by mutated pirates. They had piscine features, such as shark jaws, crab claws, and pufferfish spines. Any of the crew who resisted the creatures were killed and those who remain were taken aboard as hostages.

entries.name: Repeat
entries: If this encounter occurs again, consider replacing the {@creature ghost|mm|ghosts} with {@creature specter|mm|specters} or {@creature poltergeist|mm|poltergeists} who cannot be brought to an eternal rest.

footnotes.name: Giant Crab
entries: A {@creature giant crab} scuttles out from a kelp forest or coastal cave and attacks a random character. The target is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher. The crab attempts to {@action grapple} the character, then drop overboard with them and drown them (see "{@book Suffocating|phb|8|Suffocating|0}" in chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook}). If the encounter occurs at sea, the crab claws its way up the hull to ambush the character.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, consider using a {@creature hulking crab|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}).

footnotes.name: Giant Shark
entries: A {@creature giant shark} surges through the water toward the party and attacks a random character. The size of the creature makes it impossible to miss, and the characters each have a turn to try and flee or {@action hide} before it arrives and attacks. Giant sharks are 30 feet long and utterly fearless.

entries.name: Ships
entries: If this encounter occurs while the characters are on a ship, the giant shark attacks whatever vessel the characters are on. These enormous fish are capable of sinking smaller ships but are just as likely to ram larger ones to try and knock unsuspecting crew overboard. If the shark rams the ship, and characters on deck must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or be thrown overboard.

footnotes.name: Harpies
entries: A beautiful song carries in on the wind toward the party. Flying toward them are {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}. As soon as the {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} are within 300 feet, they use their luring song to try and charm the characters. The {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} attempt to lure any enthralled characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes or overboard a ship. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} might also pair up to {@action grapple} a character and fly off with them to their lair. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} typically lair in isolated caves accessible only by climbing, such as rocky outcroppings, clifftops or skerries.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each harpy has a {@chance 25} chance of wearing some basic jewellery worth 50 gp, such as a silver necklace or bronze anklet.

footnotes.name: Iceberg
entries: Floating in the ocean is an iceberg. Whilst this may not be troublesome on a clear day, it can be dangerous when unnoticed, such as at night or in heavy fog.

If a collision with the iceberg seems imminent, have everyone aboard the vessel make a DC 15 group Dexterity check to avoid hitting the berg. If the group check succeeds, the collision is avoided. Otherwise, the ship takes {@damage 10d10} bludgeoning damage from the collision, and everyone aboard must make a DC 10 Strength or Dexterity saving throw to avoid falling overboard.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Large icebergs are often home to monsters that favour an arctic environment. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the iceberg has one {@creature frost giant}, one {@creature young remorhaz}, {@dice 2d4} {@creature winter wolf|mm|winter wolves} or {@dice 2d6+2} {@creature ice mephit|mm|ice mephits} living on it.

entries.name: No Ice?
entries: If it doesn't make sense for ice to be where your characters are exploring, you could swap the berg for a rocky island, a coral reef, an abandoned warship, or a magical iceberg.

footnotes.name: Kelpie
entries: A hypnotic {@creature kelpie|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}), an intelligent, aquatic plant that resembles a pile of seaweed, tries to lure one of the characters to their death. The {@creature kelpie|tftyp} can take the form of a {@filter Small, Medium or Large beast or humanoid|bestiary|size=S;M;L|type=beast;humanoid}, and uses this to its advantage, posing as a desirable creature such as a giant sea horse, or a stranded commoner drowning in rough seas.

footnotes.name: Killer Whales
entries: The party is attacked by a pod of {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature killer whale|mm|killer whales} who surge toward them through the water. If the characters are on a vessel that couldn't be capsized by the orcas, they simply notice them hunting not far from the ship.

footnotes.name: Kraken Sighting
entries: A huge shadow passes beneath the vessel on which the party sail. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) or Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check allows characters to realise that the form is a {@creature kraken}. It pays no attention to the ship unless attacked by the crew.
Obviously, any crew members who notice the beast are be terrified, fleeing into the belly of the ship, muttering prayers or climbing up rigging.

If you wish, the kraken could be {@creature Slarkrethel|SKT} (see {@adventure chapter 5|CallfromtheDeep|9} for his full statistics). This gives the characters the chance to realise that not all is well with the kraken, thanks to the exposed brain, which is actually Zellix'Phor the {@creature elder brain|vgm}.

footnotes.name: Kraken Society Cultists
entries: The characters encounter a sullen group of {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature spy|mm|spies} or {@creature cultist|mm|cultists} wearing grey hooded cloaks, led by a {@creature cult fanatic} wearing a purple robe over a {@item breastplate|phb} (AC 16) embossed with a kraken design. These minor agents of the society are on a mission to gather information about merchant movements, explore unmapped coastline, sabotage Lord's Alliance ships or hire pirate crews. These low-ranking members of the cult have no idea that they are genuinely working for a kraken, and certainly have no idea that said kraken has been dominated by an elder brain.

A character can determine that the cultists are members of the Kraken Society with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. The cultists pass by unless they are attacked, in which case they retaliate with lethal force. Only the {@creature cult fanatic} leader knows what their specific mission is, and if the characters question them, Zellix'Phor can use an action on its turn to telepathically deal 40 psychic damage to them, enough to kill them instantly.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each cultist carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The leader's ornamented {@item breastplate|phb} is worth 450 gp, and they carry a pouch containing {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d4} gems worth 50 gp each. At the DM's discretion, the cultists could be carrying correspondence or maps pertaining to the characters' quests to help get them moving in the right direction.

footnotes.name: Lycanthropes
entries: Depending on where the characters are exploring, they come across one or more lycanthropes. The lycanthropes might be initially encountered in their animal, hybrid, or humanoid form depending on the focus of the encounter.

entries.name: Coast, Sea & Underwater
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature wereshark|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) hunting during the day or camping at night. Weresharks are loners and tend to be rude or hostile. If a {@creature wereshark|CallfromtheDeep} gets a taste for humanoid flesh, it takes great mental fortitude to oppress the urge to kill.

footnotes.name: Mephits
entries: The characters might encounter {@creature dust mephit|mm|dust mephits}, {@creature ice mephit|mm|ice mephits}, {@creature mud mephit|mm|mud mephits}, or {@creature steam mephit|mm|steam mephits} (each appearing as a group of {@dice 2d6}). The mephits don't attack unless they outnumber the characters two to one, but they're reluctant to be helpful unless they themselves are outnumbered.

entries.name: At Sea
entries: The characters encounter {@item sailing ship|CallfromtheDeep} or {@item cog|CallfromtheDeep} boat crewed by {@dice 2d6 + 10} people (use the {@creature commoner} stat block unless otherwise noted below). The ship is headed for the nearest safe port. The encounter might be one of the following:

items: Friendly scrimshanders transporting {@dice 2d4} boxes of scrimshaw worth 50 gp per box.
Friendly mercers transporting {@dice 2d4} rolls of fine elven silk worth 100 gp per bundle.
Haughty, incredibly rich spice merchants with a hold full of pouches of {@item cinnamon|phb}, {@item saffron|phb}, {@item pepper|phb}, and {@item salt|phb} worth 15 gp a pouch.
Hostile pirates (NE Northlander {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}) in a stolen ship posing as friendly traders to lure in potential victims.
A family fleeing their coastal village in a {@item rowboat|CallfromtheDeep} in the wake of rumours of pirate attacks; the boat contains their food and other mundane belongings.
Five friendly merchants transporting timber for boat building; any other persons present are Zhentarim {@creature guard|mm|guards} (N humans of various ethnicities) hired to ward off pirates.

Friendly Zhentarim mercenaries (NG {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities) transporting thirty {@item longsword|phb|longswords} (worth 15 gp each) and fifty {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} (worth 10 gp each) to a Zhent merchant waiting for them in the nearest port.

footnotes.name: Merfolk
entries: Emerging from the depths are a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature merfolk} traders. These peaceful, water-dwelling folk come to the surface in order to trade with passing ships. They don't value gold but instead delight in useful magical items or metal weapons that they lack the ability to craft. In return, they can offer treasures of the deep such as {@item pearl|dmg|pearls}, necklaces, and armour made of corals, glowing jellyfish in glass jars and magic potions. They may also have strange artifacts that they have scavenged from the depths such as parts of the crash-landed Illithid ship. Crew members often become infatuated with {@creature merfolk} and go on about them for days after the encounter.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The merfolk group carry treasures worth 250 gp. There is a {@chance 50} chance that they carry {@dice 1d4} magic items, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Merrow
entries: The characters encounter {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature merrow} in the depths. They hunt humanoids in fishing vessels or on the coast. Their main tactic is to harpoon creatures into the water and drown them, taking their corpses down to underwater grottoes to feed. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the merrow have {@dice 1d4} {@creature merfolk} prisoners with them, bound in thick kelp rope. The {@creature merfolk} are from a nearby settlement where the characters could take refuge should they choose to free the prisoners.

footnotes.name: Nereid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature nereid|tftyp} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}); a fey creature of otherworldly beauty. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the neried is good aligned and can help guide the characters through the next leg of their journey or point them in the direction of a previously unknown location. An evil aligned nereid convinces the characters into believing that they are good before using their drowning kiss and aquatic invisibility to launch a deadly surprise attack.

footnotes.name: NPC in the Water
entries: Clinging to a piece of flotsam, a floating tree trunk or barrel is a stranded individual who can foreshadow future events and give the characters information about events happening within the Realms if they are saved. The  could be anyone the DM chooses, but examples of potential characters are listed below:

Renk (NE male half-orc {@creature thug}) is a pirate from a ship called 'The Horizon Treader'. He bargains for his life with information about pirate activity along the Sword Coast and the Island Kingdoms. If rescued, he clams up straight away. A successful DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check is enough to get him talking again. The check can be made with advantage if Renk's life is put at risk.
Renk knows that his captain answered to a pirate-king, raiding the ships and villages that they choose. He also knows that the pirates are trying to take prisoners rather than treasure or goods.

items: Alethra Alnor (LG female Illuskan human {@creature noble}) is a merchant from a ship named 'Mirar's Bounty'. She hails from Luskan. Normally their trade is protected thanks to Ship Kurth (see "{@book Luskan|scag|2|Luskan|0}" in chapter 2| of the {@i Sword Coast Adventurer's Guide} for more information on the Ships of Luskan). She tells the characters that Luskan has remained relatively untouched by the pirate raids thanks to the protection of the Ships, but those who trade further abroad cannot be protected. This fate befell her ship, Mirar's Bounty, which was sunk near the Moonshae Isles. As well as information, Alethra rewards each player with a {@item moonstone} (50gp each).

Urth Stormaxe (CN male Northlander human {@creature berserker}) is a native of Tuern, a violent island filled with vicious raiders. Urth claims his longship was sunk by sahuagin who seemed possessed with great intelligence.

footnotes.name: Passing Warship
entries: There is a {@chance 50|50%} chance of this {@item warship|CallfromtheDeep} being friendly or hostile. Friendly {@item warship|CallfromtheDeep|warships} include vessels from Neverwinter, Waterdeep, Baldur's Gate or Gundarlun. Hostile ships might come from Luskan, Tuern, Purple Rocks or other Northlander Isles.

Ships from major cities along the Sword Coast take the form of {@item galley|CallfromtheDeep|galleys} or {@item warship|CallfromtheDeep|warships} crewed by {@creature guard|mm|guards} or {@creature veteran|mm|veterans}. Those from island kingdoms are typically {@item longship|CallfromtheDeep|longships} crewed by {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors} or {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}.

footnotes.name: Pirate Ship
entries: A ship sailing a black flag appears on the horizon. Panic begins to spread through the crew as word gets around that pirates have been sighted. As the speedy ship begins to gain on the characters' vessel, characters can attempt to avoid combat, but if that fails they have to fight the raiders hand-to-hand.

entries.name: Skill Challenge
entries: The characters must succeed on three DC 15 checks before failing three checks in order to out-navigate and escape the pirates. Allow any reasonable skill to be used, such as the following examples:

items: Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to row the ship and help it gain speed.
Dexterity check to wrangle the sails into a new position.
Constitution check to row at top speed despite burning muscles.
Intelligence check to calculate the best angle of escape.
Chequeo de Sabiduría ({@skill Perception}) para vigilar la trayectoria del barco pirata.
Charisma ({@skill Performance}) check to inspire the rest of the crew.

entries: If the characters fail three checks before succeeding on three, the pirates catch up.

Pirates typically crew {@item sailing ship|CallfromtheDeep|sailing ships}, which require a crew of twenty; a mixture of {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, {@creature thug|mm|thugs}, {@creature swashbuckler|vgm|swashbucklers}, and {@creature berserker|mm|berserkers}. Once within 120 feet of the character's ship, the pirates unleash a volley of {@item heavy crossbow|phb} {@item crossbow bolt|phb|bolts} and {@item javelin|phb|javelins}. These are connected to ropes which allow them to anchor the two ships together. It then takes three group actions for the pirate crew to draw the two ships together. At this point, the pirate crew storm and board the characters' ship using planks, ropes, and {@item grappling hook|phb|grappling hooks}. Melee combat ensues on deck.

There is a {@chance 20|20%} chance that the crew of the ship are peppered with {@creature sea spawn|CallfromtheDeep} and {@creature deep scion|vgm|deep scions}. They are there on behalf of the Kraken Society, who are being manipulated by Zellix'Phor the {@creature Elder Brain|vgm}.

If the party are all knocked {@condition unconscious} by the pirates, they do not kill them. Instead, the party awakens a day later in shackles in the hull of the pirate ship. Give them plenty of chances to escape, but if they cannot, have the pirate ship attacked by a friendly {@item warship|CallfromtheDeep} who liberate the characters.
{@adventure Appendix D|CallfromtheDeep|14|Example Ships & Crew} gives some examples of other ships, potential captains, treasure items and pirate companies or affiliations.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: As well as their ship, each pirate crew has a cargo of treasure and possibly captured slaves. See {@adventure Appendix D|CallfromtheDeep|14|Ship Treasure|0} for more details or roll on the "{@table Treasure Hoard: Challenge 0—4}" table in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Sahuagin
entries: The party encounter a gang of {@dice 2d4 + 2} {@creature sahuagin} accompanied by {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks}. There is a {@chance 20} chance that the hunting party is led by a {@creature sahuagin priestess} or a {@creature sahuagin raider|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}). The {@creature sahuagin} attempt to throw characters into the water where the {@creature hunter shark|mm|sharks} viciously maul them. {@creature Sahuagin} have a hatred for elves, and always attack elven characters first if possible.

The sea devils have been stirred up by the influence of Zellix'Phor. Previously, the {@creature sahuagin} had little to do with Slarkrethel but since the discovery of the nautiloid crash, things have changed. Pieces of strange mind flayer technology have made their way into the hands of the {@creature sahuagin}, who have distributed it throughout their tribes, spreading the influence of the elder brain. The sea devils may carry with them {@item spear|phb|spears} made of strange metal, foreign tablets with {@language Qualith|vgm} inscriptions, or even weapons created by the illithid for them (see {@book Volo's Guide to Monsters|vgm|0|Mind Flayers: Scourge of Worlds}).
{@creature Sahuagin} carry exotic weapons adorned with pearls, coral and other naturally beautiful items. Each weapon is worth twice its normal value.
entries.name: Treasure

footnotes.name: Salty Sea Dogs
entries: Whilst travelling the high seas, the party encounter an NPC (or group thereof) who provide the chance for roleplay, gaining allies, making enemies, or gathering information:

entries.name: Flotsam & Jetsam
entries: (CN male and female {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}) This pair of {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} have fashioned themselves a barely seaworthy vessel from an old {@item barrel|phb}, using a tablecloth for a sail. They both have the additional skill: {@skill Sleight of Hand} {@dice 1d20+6|+6} and are kleptomaniacs. The {@creature goblin|mm|goblins} can become steadfast allies, who happily accompany the crew rather than remain in their dangerous little boat. They are also willing to "... swashbuckle..." alongside the characters but might not be able to resist pinching a particularly shiny piece of treasure from them should the opportunity arise.

entries.name: Anka
entries: (NN female {@creature anka|CallfromtheDeep|ogre} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12})). Previously the first mate of the notorious Captain Callous, {@creature Anka|CallfromtheDeep} made her last dim-witted mistake upon 'The Devil's Fin' and was forced to walk the plank by the captain. The characters encounter her 'starfished' on her back in the water, desperately trying to stay afloat. {@creature Anka|CallfromtheDeep|Anka's} left arm has been replaced with a huge anchor which is slowly dragging her down. If saved, {@creature Anka|CallfromtheDeep} temporarily allies with the characters, helping them track Captain Callous. Despite this, a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check by Captain Callous causes her to come back to his side.

entries.name: T'zen'lix
entries: (LE male {@creature neogi|vgm}). T'zen'lix is an alien, spiderlike creature from the Astral Plane that accidently ended up here after stowing away on the nautiloid. When it crashlanded, 'Lix managed to enslave a farmer from Gundarlun and escape. Since then, 'Lix has been on a whirlwind ride discovering that wanton control over living beings often ends in sticky situations. 'Lix mostly wants to get back to the Astral Plane and joins together with the characters if they can help him achieve this goal. 'Lix doesn't think twice about mind controlling the characters to alleviate even the smallest of stresses for himself.

entries.name: Mei Ling
entries: (LE female {@creature vampire} with a swim speed of 30 ft.) Mei Ling is a vampire who lives in the underwater ruins of Narino, north of Mintarn. Normally Mei Ling feeds on the blood of merfolk and sea elves, but from time to time she rises from her underwater lair to sample Tarnian blood and make mischief. She might clamber aboard the ship and drain the blood of a Tarnian crew member, try to sabotage the vessel, or turn the cabin boy into a {@creature vampire spawn}. Mei Ling doesn't consider the ocean to be running water. For more information about Mei Ling and Narino, see "{@adventure Open Lord Dagult Neverember's Quest|CallfromtheDeep|3|Dagult Neverember's Quest|0}" in {@adventure chapter 2|CallfromtheDeep|3}.

entries.name: Toroa
entries: (CN female Chultan human {@creature war priest|vgm} of Kahulla) Hailing from a far-flung island nation south of the Sword Coast, Toroa belongs to The Chosen of the Stormheart, an order of clerics sent out into the world to chase down the largest storms and commune with their patron goddess Kahulla, an aspect of {@deity Talos|Faerûnian|scag}. Toroa is hot on the tail of an enormous tempest that is, unbeknownst to her, a {@creature storm giant quintessent|vgm}. Torora has dusky skin, electric blue hair and a preference for lightning magic.

footnotes.name: Sea Hags
entries: The characters encounter three {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} that comprise a coven. Their favourite trick is to pretend to be stranded or wounded peasants in need of rescue in a damaged or beached rowboat.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters defeat the {@creature sea hag|mm|sea hags} and search the area, roll twice on {@table Magic Item Table A} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine what they find. Whatever treasure the hags have is stowed inside a rotted wooden {@item chest|phb}.

footnotes.name: Sharks
entries: The characters are attacked by either {@dice 1d3} {@creature hunter shark|mm|hunter sharks} or {@dice 2d4} {@creature reef shark|mm|reef sharks} depending on what variety of location they are in. Characters in large ships that could not be capsized by the sharks can easily avoid this encounter, so consider having it occur at a later date when a character or crew member has fallen overboard.

footnotes.name: Storm Giant
entries: Looming up ahead of the characters, either rising from the water, sailing in an enormous dinghy or lumbering along the sea floor is a lone {@creature storm giant}. {@creature Storm giant|mm|Storm giants} are typically good aligned and willing to help the characters if they explain their situation. A successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check is enough to convince a giant to fight with the party during their next combat. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the giant can escort the characters to Maelstrom (see "Maelstrom" in chapter 3).

footnotes.name: Trolls
entries: The characters are ambushed by {@dice 1d2} {@creature troll|mm|trolls}. They attack from behind ridges, thickets, and even kelp forests. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 11 or higher notice the {@creature troll|mm|trolls} from a safe distance and can attempt to flee, otherwise the characters are surprised.

entries.name: Sea & Underwater
entries: Saltwater trolls are called {@creature scrag|CallfromtheDeep|scrags}. They use the {@creature troll} stat block with the following changes:

items: Los escarabajos tienen una velocidad de nado de 30 pies.

items.name: Amphibious
entries: El scrag puede respirar aire y agua.

items.name: Aquatic Regeneration
entries: The scrag regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it fully submerged in water. If the scrag takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the scrag's next turn. The scrag only dies if it starts its turn with 0 hit points and doesn't regenerate.

footnotes.name: Vodyanoi
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature vodyanoi|CallfromtheDeep} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) which attacks a random character or their ship. These relatives of the {@creature umber hulk} are capable of punching through ship hulls or capsizing smaller vessels.

footnotes.name: Whirlpool
entries: The roar of the waves increases and spray shoots into the air. A whirlpool forms {@dice 1d4 × 10} feet away from characters or their ship, the pull of which can immediately be felt.

The whirlpool forms a vortex that is 5 feet wide at the base, 50 feet wide at the top, and 25 feet tall. Any creature or object in the water and within 25 feet of the vortex is pulled 10 feet toward it. A creature can swim away from the vortex with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A ship can be rowed away if the crew succeed on a the same group check.

A creature or object that enters the vortex for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage and is caught in the vortex. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and isn't caught. A creature caught in the vortex can use its action to try to escape from the vortex as described above but has disadvantage on the Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to do so. A ship's crew can attempt the same group check.
A creature pulled beneath the waves must hold its breath or begin to drown (see chapter 8 of the {@i Player's Handbook} for rules on "{@book Suffocating|phb|8|Suffocating|0}").

table.name: Random Encounters; Mountains
rows: {@footnote Hill giants|This encounter's dice range is given as 39–45 in the source, which overlaps with the Knight encounter. This is modified here to prevent the table from breaking.

footnotes.name: Barbarians
entries: The characters encounter a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors}, led by a {@creature berserker}. If the encounter occurs during the day, the barbarians are prowling the countryside while hunting wild game; if the encounter occurs at night, they are camped.

entries.name: The North
entries: If this encounter occurs in The North, the characters encounter an Uthgardt Barbarian tribe, led by an {@creature Uthgardt shaman|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) with an additional {@creature berserker} bodyguard.

footnotes.name: Blood Hawks
entries: A vicious kettle of {@dice 2d4+2} {@creature blood hawk|mm|blood hawks} attacks the party from above. These crimson raptors are fearless and attack large creatures without second thought. The hawks target already injured characters or those who look weaker than the rest of the party.

footnotes.name: Druid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature druid} who might be a member of the Emerald Enclave or simply devoted to protecting a certain area of wilderness. Most druids are happy to give guidance on traversing their lands, provided the characters are respectful of the environment on their travels. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the druid is accompanied by an animal companion. Two sample druids are presented below, but you can create others.

Jillian Leafgather (NG female lightfoot halfling) is a member of the Emerald Enclave accompanied by her massive, relentlessly slobbering {@creature mastiff}, Bungo. Jillian despises animal cruelty, and even considers insulting animals verbally to be intolerable. She knows a few shortcuts around the Sword Mountains and Neverwinter Wood, which she happily shares with characters in need. The shortcuts allow characters to move at a fast pace without any penalties.

Orsik Oakenheim (CE male mountain dwarf) is wild and rugged. He believes that the wilds should overtake civilisation, and all folk should go back to living as nomadic tribes in the wilderness. He wears a huge fur coat and trapper hat which conceals eight {@creature twig blight|mm|twig blights}. Orsik happily converses with characters, but if he deems them too involved with society, he tries to orchestrate their deaths. This can be achieved by sending characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes, {@trap quicksand} or predator territory. He also sends his {@creature twig blight|mm|blights} to steal things from the characters such as identification papers, faction emblems or {@item holy symbol|phb|holy symbols}.

footnotes.name: Giant Spider
entries: The characters are ambushed by a {@creature giant spider}.

entries.name: Mountain
entries: A random character inadvertently blunders into the spider's {@trap webs|dmg|web} (see "{@book Dungeon Hazards|dmg|5|Dungeon Hazards|0}" in chapter 5 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}). The spider quickly emerges from a concealed cave to gather its dinner

footnotes.name: Goblinoids
entries: A typical goblin patrol or hunting party consists of a {@creature goblin boss} leading {@dice 2d6 + 3} {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}. Goblins tend to have their own territories which they seldom leave. Goblins prefer to hunt at night and lay low in ambush positions during the day.

A night encounter with goblins involves an attack on the characters' camp. A character standing watch with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher detects the goblins moving into attack positions and can rouse the rest of the party. If no one on watch notices the goblins, all characters are surprised.

If this encounter occurs while the characters are traveling during the day, any characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher spots the tell-tale signs of an ambush: disadvantageous terrain coupled with an eerie silence not normal for the environment.

Goblins bargain for their lives if captured. If the characters can force or coerce a vow of cooperation from goblin prisoners, they will serve as guides. Goblins in their home territory have the following additional skill: {@skill Survival} {@dice 1d20+1|+1}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The gang of goblins have amassed 50 gp of assorted goods from ambushing travellers.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, there is a {@chance 50} chance that the goblins are led by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature bugbear|mm|bugbears} and the {@creature goblin boss} is replaced by a {@creature bugbear chief}. When under the command of bugbears, goblins do not flee unless all the bugbears are killed.

footnotes.name: Harpies
entries: A beautiful song carries in on the wind toward the party. Flying toward them are {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}. As soon as the {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} are within 300 feet, they use their luring song to try and charm the characters. The {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} attempt to lure any enthralled characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes or overboard a ship. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} might also pair up to {@action grapple} a character and fly off with them to their lair. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} typically lair in isolated caves accessible only by climbing, such as rocky outcroppings, clifftops or skerries.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each harpy has a {@chance 25} chance of wearing some basic jewellery worth 50 gp, such as a silver necklace or bronze anklet.

footnotes.name: Hill Giants
entries: A band of {@dice 1d3} {@creature hill giant|mm|hill giants} is searching for homesteads to pillage or bands of travellers to capture. The giants hurl rocks at any small folk they see. {@creature Hill giant|mm|Hill giants} are dim creatures and are easily tricked by misdirection and illusions. Characters might even be able to slip past a group of them while they argue with each other about who has the biggest belly, or whose feet smell the worst.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The giants carry a sack with them which contains a bundle of mundane items such as wagon wheels, tombstones, beehives and casks of ale. There is {@chance 25} chance that the bag also contains Garrin Brandybrush (NG male Stout halfling {@creature commoner} with 0 hit points), three cats stolen by accident from a nearby farm, or one {@creature boar} to which the giants have tied half a dozen humanoid skulls.

footnotes.name: Knight
entries: The Order of the Gauntlet is taking strides to deal with the pirate threat. The characters encounter a {@creature knight} of the order mounted on a {@creature warhorse} clad in {@item chain mail|phb} {@item barding|phb} (AC 16). There is a {@chance 50} chance that the {@creature knight} has a squire–a {@creature guard} mounted on an unarmoured {@creature warhorse}. Two sample knights are presented below.

Marcheon Amander Chilcott (LG non-binary Illuskan human {@creature knight} of {@deity Tyr|Faerûnian|scag}) is a gallant yet ferocious Knight of the Merciful Sword who prefers to reform rather than destroy criminals. Chilcott and her squire recently raided a smuggler's cove filled with pirates and captured their leader, Captain Uthak 'Nightbringer' Katho-Olavi (NE male goliath {@creature berserker}). Nightbringer is an immensely tall goliath, covered in wave tattoos and bound with three pairs of {@item manacles|phb}. Marcheon Chilcott asks the characters to escort the captain to the nearest settlement while she heads back to the cove to ensure it is securely boarded up.

Lady Luciette Falconcrown (NG female Chondathan human {@creature knight} of {@deity Helm|Faerûnian|scag}) is a member of the Order of the Gilded Eye from Helm's Hold. Lady Falconcrown believes that evil should be actively sought out and punished before it has a chance to rear its ugly head. She wears a golden gauntlet emblazoned with a weeping eye on her right hand which marks her allegiance. Lady Falconcrown is currently searching for Zhentarim agents who she believes should be held accountable for their faction's misdemeanours. She asks the characters to give up anyone they know who is affiliated with the Black Network and tells them to take her to the traitors, so she can personally deliver them to justice.

footnotes.name: Kraken Society Cultists
entries: The characters encounter a sullen group of {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature spy|mm|spies} or {@creature cultist|mm|cultists} wearing grey hooded cloaks, led by a {@creature cult fanatic} wearing a purple robe over a {@item breastplate|phb} (AC 16) embossed with a kraken design. These minor agents of the society are on a mission to gather information about merchant movements, explore unmapped coastline, sabotage Lord's Alliance ships or hire pirate crews. These low-ranking members of the cult have no idea that they are genuinely working for a kraken, and certainly have no idea that said kraken has been dominated by an elder brain.

A character can determine that the cultists are members of the Kraken Society with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. The cultists pass by unless they are attacked, in which case they retaliate with lethal force. Only the {@creature cult fanatic} leader knows what their specific mission is, and if the characters question them, Zellix'Phor can use an action on its turn to telepathically deal 40 psychic damage to them, enough to kill them instantly.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each cultist carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The leader's ornamented {@item breastplate|phb} is worth 450 gp, and they carry a pouch containing {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d4} gems worth 50 gp each. At the DM's discretion, the cultists could be carrying correspondence or maps pertaining to the characters' quests to help get them moving in the right direction.

footnotes.name: Manticore
entries: A {@creature manticore} attacks the party from its aerial vantage point, trying to kill a random character with its tail spikes and carry them back to its lair to devour. The {@creature manticore} may flee from battle if wounded, only to return the next day to continue to harass the characters. If the characters are incapable of killing the monstrosity, it happily offers to leave them be if they offer it a sacrifice or tribute. Anything worth less than 100 gp seriously offends the creature, who flies into a rage and wildly attacks. Each {@creature manticore} has its own malicious personality and might refer to itself as the Scourge of Gundarlun or a similar title.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters can track the {@creature manticore} back to its lair with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check. Normally a cave in a cliff face or mountainside, the lair contains 300 gp of coins and gems and has a {@chance 25} chance of containing {@dice 1d3} magic items, determined by rolling on {@table Magic Item Table C} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

footnotes.name: Mephits
entries: The characters might encounter {@creature dust mephit|mm|dust mephits}, {@creature ice mephit|mm|ice mephits}, {@creature mud mephit|mm|mud mephits}, or {@creature steam mephit|mm|steam mephits} (each appearing as a group of {@dice 2d6}). The mephits don't attack unless they outnumber the characters two to one, but they're reluctant to be helpful unless they themselves are outnumbered.

entries.name: On Land
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature draft horse} pulling a {@item wagon|phb}. Accompanying the {@item wagon|phb} are {@dice 1d6 - 1} people (use the {@creature commoner} stat block unless otherwise noted below). If the die result indicates that no one is present, it means the drivers are either missing or dead, leaving the horse and {@item wagon|phb} unattended. If one or more people are present, assume that they are guiding the {@item wagon|phb} toward the nearest settlement. The encounter might be one of the following:

items: Friendly furriers transporting {@dice 2d4} bundles of animal pelts worth 50 gp per bundle.
Friendly peddlers transporting {@dice 3d6} ten-gallon kegs of dwarven ale worth 5 gp each.
Friendly, dirt-poor musicians looking for a tavern; the wagon holds their instruments and gear.
Hostile {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} (NE Illuskan humans) posing as friendly traders, transporting a stolen wagon laden with foodstuffs to their encampment.
A family fleeing their coastal village in the wake of rumours of pirate attacks; the wagon contains their food and their mundane belongings.

A friendly merchant transporting {@dice 2d4} {@creature pig|skt|pigs} worth 3 gp each; any other persons present are Zhentarim {@creature guard|mm|guards} (N humans of various ethnicities) hired to ward off bandits.

Friendly Zhentarim mercenaries (NG human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities) transporting thirty {@item longsword|phb|longswords} (worth 15 gp each) and fifty {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} (worth 10 gp each) to a Zhent merchant waiting for them in the nearest settlement.

footnotes.name: Mountain Lion
entries: A muscular {@creature lion|mm|{@footnote mountain lion|There is no 'mountain lion' anywhere in this book or other officially-published material. The generic lion has been linked instead.} pounces on the smallest character in the party and attempts to drag them off to its nearby den. The character is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher.

footnotes.name: Ogres
entries: The characters hear loud, deep voices and spot {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} from a safe distance away. The big dummies are lost and trying to find their way home. The characters catch them in the middle of a loud argument about which direction they should go and can easily avoid the {@creature ogre|mm|ogres} or take them by surprise.

footnotes.name: Orcs
entries: The characters come across {@dice 3d6 + 2} {@creature orc|mm|orcs}. There is a {@chance 25} chance that these orcs have prisoners in tow. A sample group of prisoners is presented here, but you can create others.

The prisoners are {@dice 1d4 + 2} rock gnome {@creature commoner|mm|commoners} belonging to the Frackle clan. The oldest among them is a barmy old tinker named Nissanab 'Fizzlebang' Frackle. The {@creature orc|mm|orcs} smoked out the Frackle burrow and captured these family members as they tried to flee. The prisoners are smoke-stained and coughing. The Frackles have managed to create rudimentary firearms, including a {@item pistol} which the lead {@creature orc} has stolen, though he only has 5 bullets. Fizzlebang has a pouch of 25 additional bullets. For more information on firearms and explosives, see chapter 9, "{@book Dungeon Master's Workshop|dmg|9|Firearms|0}," of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: If the characters escort the Frackles back to their burrow, the gnomes are reunited with the members of their family who avoided capture. One of them rewards the party with a family heirloom (a magic item) hidden in the burnt remains of the family home. Roll on {@table Magic Item Table F} in chapter 7 of the {@i Dungeon Master's Guide} to determine the item.

footnotes.name: Ranger
entries: The characters encounter a helpful ranger; a member of the Emerald Enclave or simply a wilderness wanderer. The ranger is happy to serve as a guide or source of information. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the ranger has a {@creature riding horse}, one or more beast companions, or both. A ranger with neither travels alone on foot. Two sample rangers are presented below, but you can create others:

Berri (CG female firbolg {@creature scout}) can cast {@spell detect magic} and {@spell disguise self}. She only appears to characters that are lost or in desperate need. She initially appears as an elf to avoid revealing her true identity, but if the characters are kind, she reveals her true form. Berri always carries dried fruit in small cloth parcels which she might leave for desperate adventurers. She also makes sure to carry a bundle of vials filled with an invigorating alcoholic draft which puts a drinker under the effects of a {@spell bless} spell for 1 hour.

Throkk Ampleford (CN male half-orc {@creature archer|vgm} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12})) is an incredible game hunter who has been living on The High Moor for the past decade. He was born in Neverwinter, but outcast because of his orcish heritage. Throkk has a pet {@creature hawk} named Streak who's catches rabbits and squirrels. Throkk has the additional skill: {@skill Survival} {@dice 1d20+5|+5}. He can use his knowledge of the local area to help characters hunt. Throkk also loves to fletch and crafts arrows for the characters as a gift before they part ways.

footnotes.name: Travellers
entries: The characters encounter one or more travellers (use the {@creature commoner} stat block) with a tale to tell:

entries.name: Mountains
entries: {@dice 1d4} miners who've heard there's more money in being a lumberjack, and are headed to the nearest woods to start up.

footnotes.name: Trolls
entries: The characters are ambushed by {@dice 1d2} {@creature troll|mm|trolls}. They attack from behind ridges, thickets, and even kelp forests. Characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 11 or higher notice the {@creature troll|mm|trolls} from a safe distance and can attempt to flee, otherwise the characters are surprised.

footnotes.name: Wolves
entries: The party encounter a pack of {@dice 1d6 + 5} {@creature wolf|mm|wolves}.

entries.name: Night
entries: The {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} are hunting and attack the characters' camp. A character on watch with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 14 or higher notices the pack surveying the camp. If unnoticed, the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} surprise the characters.

entries.name: Day
entries: The characters discover a den where the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} are sleeping. Unless the party disguise their scent, the {@creature wolf|mm|wolves} attack their camp the following night.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, the pack is accompanied by {@dice 1d3} {@creature dire wolf|mm|dire wolves}.

footnotes.name: Ankheg
entries: A group of {@dice 1d3} {@creature ankheg|mm|ankhegs} bursts up from beneath the ground to ambush the characters. Any character without {@sense tremorsense|MM} is surprised by the attack. Ankhegs prefer Small creatures, which they grab with their mandibles and drag back underground to consume.

footnotes.name: Bandits
entries: A marauding gang of bandits confronts the party. The gang consists of a {@creature bandit captain} and {@dice 3d6 + 2} {@creature bandit|mm|bandits}, all wearing cloaks and mounted on {@creature riding horse|mm|riding horses}. There is a {@chance 25} chance that the bandits attack without provocation. Otherwise, the captain promises not to attack in exchange for a toll (no less than 100 gp worth of treasure). If the characters pay up, the captain bids them a safe journey before departing peacefully.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each bandit carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. The bandit captain's pouch holds {@dice 2d10} gp and {@dice 1d6} gems worth 100 gp each.

footnotes.name: Barbarians
entries: The characters encounter a group of {@dice 2d6 + 2} {@creature tribal warrior|mm|tribal warriors}, led by a {@creature berserker}. If the encounter occurs during the day, the barbarians are prowling the countryside while hunting wild game; if the encounter occurs at night, they are camped.

entries.name: The North
entries: If this encounter occurs in The North, the characters encounter an Uthgardt Barbarian tribe, led by an {@creature Uthgardt shaman|SKT} ({@adventure appendix B|CallfromtheDeep|12}) with an additional {@creature berserker} bodyguard.

footnotes.name: Blood Hawks
entries: A vicious kettle of {@dice 2d4+2} {@creature blood hawk|mm|blood hawks} attacks the party from above. These crimson raptors are fearless and attack large creatures without second thought. The hawks target already injured characters or those who look weaker than the rest of the party.

footnotes.name: Druid
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature druid} who might be a member of the Emerald Enclave or simply devoted to protecting a certain area of wilderness. Most druids are happy to give guidance on traversing their lands, provided the characters are respectful of the environment on their travels. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the druid is accompanied by an animal companion. Two sample druids are presented below, but you can create others.

Jillian Leafgather (NG female lightfoot halfling) is a member of the Emerald Enclave accompanied by her massive, relentlessly slobbering {@creature mastiff}, Bungo. Jillian despises animal cruelty, and even considers insulting animals verbally to be intolerable. She knows a few shortcuts around the Sword Mountains and Neverwinter Wood, which she happily shares with characters in need. The shortcuts allow characters to move at a fast pace without any penalties.

Orsik Oakenheim (CE male mountain dwarf) is wild and rugged. He believes that the wilds should overtake civilisation, and all folk should go back to living as nomadic tribes in the wilderness. He wears a huge fur coat and trapper hat which conceals eight {@creature twig blight|mm|twig blights}. Orsik happily converses with characters, but if he deems them too involved with society, he tries to orchestrate their deaths. This can be achieved by sending characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes, {@trap quicksand} or predator territory. He also sends his {@creature twig blight|mm|blights} to steal things from the characters such as identification papers, faction emblems or {@item holy symbol|phb|holy symbols}.

footnotes.name: Giant Boar
entries: The characters encounter a {@creature giant boar} chasing down a portly halfling. Unless they intervene, the halfling is caught and gored to death by the beast. The halfling's name is Nerrywill Underbarrow (NG male stout halfling {@creature commoner} with a {@item dagger|phb}, proficiency with {@item cook's utensils|phb} and the additional skill: {@skill Perception} {@dice 1d20+4|+4}). If the characters save his life, the tubby fellow pledges himself to the party for as long as he is helpful. He's a great chef and has a remarkably good eye. He keeps all his possessions in his pack and is willing to travel to the ends of the earth (and beyond) with his saviours.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Nerrywill carries a battered brass {@item spyglass|phb} engraved with his initials (850 gp), and a {@item backpack|phb} containing a {@item dagger|phb} (2 gp) and {@item cook's utensils|phb} (1 gp).

footnotes.name: Goblinoids
entries: A typical goblin patrol or hunting party consists of a {@creature goblin boss} leading {@dice 2d6 + 3} {@creature goblin|mm|goblins}. Goblins tend to have their own territories which they seldom leave. Goblins prefer to hunt at night and lay low in ambush positions during the day.

A night encounter with goblins involves an attack on the characters' camp. A character standing watch with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher detects the goblins moving into attack positions and can rouse the rest of the party. If no one on watch notices the goblins, all characters are surprised.

If this encounter occurs while the characters are traveling during the day, any characters with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher spots the tell-tale signs of an ambush: disadvantageous terrain coupled with an eerie silence not normal for the environment.

Goblins bargain for their lives if captured. If the characters can force or coerce a vow of cooperation from goblin prisoners, they will serve as guides. Goblins in their home territory have the following additional skill: {@skill Survival} {@dice 1d20+1|+1}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The gang of goblins have amassed 50 gp of assorted goods from ambushing travellers.

entries.name: Higher Levels
entries: If the characters are above 4th level, there is a {@chance 50} chance that the goblins are led by {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@creature bugbear|mm|bugbears} and the {@creature goblin boss} is replaced by a {@creature bugbear chief}. When under the command of bugbears, goblins do not flee unless all the bugbears are killed.

footnotes.name: Harpies
entries: A beautiful song carries in on the wind toward the party. Flying toward them are {@dice 1d4 + 2} {@creature harpy|mm|harpies}. As soon as the {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} are within 300 feet, they use their luring song to try and charm the characters. The {@creature harpy|mm|harpies} attempt to lure any enthralled characters into dangerous terrain such as scree slopes or overboard a ship. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} might also pair up to {@action grapple} a character and fly off with them to their lair. {@creature Harpy|mm|Harpies} typically lair in isolated caves accessible only by climbing, such as rocky outcroppings, clifftops or skerries.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each harpy has a {@chance 25} chance of wearing some basic jewellery worth 50 gp, such as a silver necklace or bronze anklet.

entries: A band of {@dice 1d3} {@creature hill giant|mm|hill giants} is searching for homesteads to pillage or bands of travellers to capture. The giants hurl rocks at any small folk they see. {@creature Hill giant|mm|Hill giants} are dim creatures and are easily tricked by misdirection and illusions. Characters might even be able to slip past a group of them while they argue with each other about who has the biggest belly, or whose feet smell the worst.

entries: The giants carry a sack with them which contains a bundle of mundane items such as wagon wheels, tombstones, beehives and casks of ale. There is {@chance 25} chance that the bag also contains Garrin Brandybrush (NG male Stout halfling {@creature commoner} with 0 hit points), three cats stolen by accident from a nearby farm, or one {@creature boar} to which the giants have tied half a dozen humanoid skulls.

entries: The Order of the Gauntlet is taking strides to deal with the pirate threat. entries: Each cultist carries a pouch containing {@dice 1d10} gp. At the DM's discretion, the cultists could be carrying correspondence or maps pertaining to the characters' quests to help get them moving in the right direction.

footnotes.name: Lycanthropes
entries: Depending on where the characters are exploring, they come across one or more lycanthropes. The lycanthropes might be initially encountered in their animal, hybrid, or humanoid form depending on the focus of the encounter.

entries.name: Hills/Moors
entries: A lone {@creature werebear} in animal form watches the party as they travel through its territory. The lycanthrope protects its territory against monstrous and humanoid intrusion. If it deems the party a danger, it might attack them to fend them off. If the party is passing through without causing much harm, the {@creature werebear} might approach them in human form to investigate their intentions.

footnotes.name: Manticore
entries: A {@creature manticore} attacks the party from its aerial vantage point, trying to kill a random character with its tail spikes and carry them back to its lair to devour. The {@creature manticore} may flee from battle if wounded, only to return the next day to continue to harass the characters. Friendly peddlers transporting {@dice 3d6} ten-gallon kegs of dwarven ale worth 5 gp each.
Friendly, dirt-poor musicians looking for a tavern; the wagon holds their instruments and gear.
Hostile {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} (NE Illuskan humans) posing as friendly traders, transporting a stolen wagon laden with foodstuffs to their encampment.

Friendly Zhentarim mercenaries (NG human {@creature veteran|mm|veterans} of various ethnicities) transporting thirty {@item longsword|phb|longswords} (worth 15 gp each) and fifty {@item shortsword|phb|shortswords} (worth 10 gp each) to a Zhent merchant waiting for them in the nearest settlement.

entries: A muscular {@creature lion|mm|{@footnote mountain lion|There is no 'mountain lion' anywhere in this book or other officially-published material. The generic lion has been linked instead.} pounces on the smallest character in the party and attempts to drag them off to its nearby den. The character is surprised unless they have a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) of 16 or higher.
